In this lesson, we will learn about a few commonly used Japanese nouns. You're already familiar with basic verbs so integrating these new nouns into your vocabulary will allow you to construct more descriptive sentences.
Let's get started with the noun for 'hotel', which in Japanese is

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: . Repeat after me, 'hotel' in Japanese is

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
.
Next, we have 'store', which is said as

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
in Japanese.
The third noun for our lesson is 'street', this is pronounced as

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: in Japanese. Try repeating after me, 'street' is

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
.
Now, we will use these nouns in a few sentences. If you remember from previous lessons, 'to walk' is '歩く' in Japanese.
So, "I am walking to the store" translates to

lang.mstts:prosody: 私はストアに歩いています

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: . Once more, "I am walking to the store" in Japanese is

lang.mstts:prosody: 私はストアに歩いています

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
.
In the context of "I see a hotel on the street", we would say

lang.mstts:prosody: 私は通りにホテルを見ます

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: in Japanese. Try repeating it, "I see a hotel on the street" is:

lang.mstts:prosody: 私は通りにホテルを見ます

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
.
Now you've learned how to say 'hotel' as

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural

in Japanese, and also used them in sentences.
Keep practicing these new words and sentences, and I'll see you for the next lesson. Happy learning!
